And while the film ends with an annoying cliffhanger, it's really the only way it should - with everything headed for disaster, and the audience wondering how on earth they're going to get out of it. It's immensely enjoyable, and I really can't wait for the third part.

title: The Hobbit: The Desolation Of Smaug is absolutely incredible!
review: I have never posted a review on a movie before, but seeing how so many people have rated this movie so low, I had do make a review. This movie is amazing! We see the continuing adventures of Bilbo and the dwarfs, plus we see Gandalf confront the Necromancer. I won't share all of this movie, but I will say: this movie has the biggest dragon I have ever seen! Smaug is a marvelous looking dragon. This movie has a lot of action sequences and Legolas even makes a big appearance! If each one of you readers are reading these bad reviews, don't pay attention to them. They have their own opinions, but I will tell you as a fellow movie-watcher. This movie does not disappoint. Definitely a 10/10 movie!

title: Bilbo is a polo warrior
review:
The film follows the titular character Bilbo Baggins as he accompanies Thorin Oakenshield and his fellow Dwarfs on a quest to reclaim the Lonely Mountain from the dragon Smaug. The film also features the vengeful pursuit of Azog the Defiler and Bolg while Gandalf the Grey investigates a growing evil at the ruins of Dol Guldur. The ensemble cast includes Ian McKellen, Martin Freeman, Richard Armitage, Benedict Cumberbatch, Evangeline Lilly, Lee Pace, Luke Evans, Ken Stott, James Nesbitt, and Orlando Bloom.

Although originally planned as a two-part adaptation, it was later announced that a third film would be produced due to the scale of the project, and was subsequently retitled The Desolation of Smaug. The screenplay was written by Fran Walsh, Philippa Boyens, Peter Jackson, and Guillermo del Toro, who was credited for his contributions before his departure in May 2010. The films were shot simultaneously in 3D at a projection rate of 48 frames per second, with principal photography taking place around New Zealand and at Pinewood Studios. Additional filming took place throughout May 2013.[4]

title: Fantastic if viewed as a movie, nothing else.
review:
Forget about the book. Hundreds of angry book fanatics fans have already stated how this action adventure slaughters the the soul of Tolkien. One thing they all seem to forget though, you're supposed to rate a movie as a movie. How good of a movie was The HObbit DOS? It was actually an amazing film. Characters like Bilbo, Gandalf, Legolas and Thorin feel real and alive, the action though a little over done is enjoyable without a doubt and the CGI is almost flawless.

PROS: As stated above, the characters are likable, some even more than in lord of the rings. The pacing is spot on, unlike AUJ. The dialoges are clever and well, there's simply a lot of things Peter did right with the movie.

CONS. What book? There's also one or two dwarfes we have yet to hear say something, that's just weird...

Final Thoughts: I personally loved the movie because I saw it as a movie and nothing else. There's a lot of dumb people who have given it one or two stars because they're either disappointed with it, or they don't agree with the direction Peter went. That does NOT mean the movie is worse than average though! Give it less than 4 and you're not good at reviewing movies if you ask me, that's just my humble opinion of course.

title: Highly enjoyable film but the adventure stays in the book
review:
Having freshly watch this film in the comfort of my own home (I missed the cinema viewing) I have to be very honest.....I really liked it!

Much better paced than the first instalment and some really great performances all round.

Sadly again the film bears little resemblance to the wonderful book on which it was based. I honestly didn't recognise most of it bar the barrel scene and a few others which is a shame because the action overtakes what was supposed to be an adventure.

In saying that though, the film rips along and there is plenty to keep the attention.

The horrible dwarven makeup is much less apparent this time around and this adds heavily to the feel, although some of the dwarfs still look far too 'man' like for me and the CGI is once again over used but to better effect this time around depicting towns and views.

As much as I love the character, the crowbarring in of Legolas was more of a distraction than a welcome addition. Besides his completely unbelievable OTT combat skills his personality is completely different than what we know. People change yes but there is no trace of the cool skilled and warm elf that we know. Instead we get a moody, angry pain in the bum and while that is OK it would have been better served with a new and different face and character.

Going back to a positive note, special mention must go to Benedict Cumberbatch and Smaug, for the performance here is truly fantastic as is the CGI dragon itself. I felt sorry for Martin freeman though as he is meant to be the main character but hardly has any screen time at all. What he has though is excellent, I just wish there was more of it.

All in all it's a vast improvement over the first film but still not as good as any of the LOTR films.

It's a shame that the book on which it is based is barely recognisable in amongst all the made up filler but then again I thought the filler was pretty good. Being a sucker for a good love story the inter racial romance was quite enjoyable and there was plenty of nice lush things to look at and move the story along.

It's definitely apparent that we are not getting an adaptation of the book from this series at all. Why beggars belief as accuracy to source material in the comic, fantasy and sci-fi worlds are of utmost paramount and this is something that we all thought Peter Jackson knew and understood as he could have easily done the book accurately and well without almost completely re-writing it.

As a film though the Hobbit:DoS is a highly enjoyable adventure film with some rich characters and nice lore and is a very welcome addition in my collection, but if I ever want to properly visit the world and adventure that Tolkien wrote about then I'll have to read the book, for there it stays and it doesn't look like it will ever leave.

title: Excellent
review: It has it all- the romance, action, danger, adventure, lust, wisdom, comedy, passion, mystery. This film is far superior to the first of the trilogy (which almost never happens). The colors were gorgeous, great pacing throughout the film, and most of the characters are great. I will say, some of the dwarfs characters I find I don't really like. I do think that the play on the dwarfs is much too... childish, but then again I did read this book when I was a child, so I can still relate oddly enough. And I must say, Benedict Cumberbatch has one of the greatest voices of all time. Overall, there was never a dull moment for me, I enjoyed every bit. This is one movie I will be able to watch time and time again.

title: Not as good as the previous movie not to mention LOTR
review:
7 out of 10 stars would normally be considered quite okay and I guess you could say that this movie is quite okay. However, it has a reputation to live up to. As a movie in the Tolkien universe and with LOTR and The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey this movie have a lot to live up to and, as far as I am concerned, it does not.

As an action/adventure/fantasy movie it is a quite okay movie. It has a lot of action of course, a lot of adventure and a lot of special effects. Of course everything plays out with the Tolkien universe as a back-drop. I guess it is rather superfluous to mention that the movie is based on the book The Hobbit by Tolkien. However it is here the problems start.

In my review of The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey the first thing that I mentioned was that you should be aware of the fact that the movie did not follow the book in any great detail and that this was quite okay since the extensions were well made. Well, it should be no surprise that the first part of this statement is valid for this movie as well. Unfortunately, whereas the first movie felt like a fluid extension of the book this one feels like it is just full of fillers.

There are a lot of cool scenes and a lot of action but it really feels like it was just put in there as fillers to showcase the special effects. Speaking of special effects, quite a few of them where rather unimpressive I have to say. The scenes where the dwarfs went down the rapids in barrels frequently looked plastic and artificial. The scenes with Smaug was not too bad even though he was quite overused but the parts around the forges was just plain ridiculous. I know it is fantasy but come one, getting them started and producing tons and tons of molten gold in a few minutes not to mention riding on molten metal without getting burned was just silly.

On the whole I found it an enjoyable movie but I was expecting more.

title: An excellent movie
review: First off, let me say that all these poor reviews of the movie are unnecessary. Directors are given creative freedom to interpret the story any way they choose, and following the book, word for word can just be just plain boring! They want the movie to be exciting, not dull, and so do I and a lot of other movie goers. I thought the movie was very entertaining. It did not drag on like some movies do. There was constant action and excitement. The one thing that did disappoint me was the end. They left me in suspense on what was going to happen with Smaug. I feel they let fans down because you give us a climactic end and then end it abruptly without a conclusion and now we have to wait for the next movie to know the outcome.

title: What happened to Gandalf?
review:
I must admit, Jackson did a great job with special effects and the majestic NZ alpine scenery. But I would have appreciated a forward or recap from when the first movie left off and this one began. I have to give it an 8 anyway. Maybe it is me, but I found the continuity and plot a bit disjointed. What happened to Gandalf the wizard? Nice to see Orlando back though.

My adult son loved it, and asked me If I had read the Hobbit. Yes I had forty years ago, but I wasn't impressed like many others were, calling it an adult fairy tale. But I loved the Lord of the Rings, and the first of this trilogy. Maybe I will hire the DVD again and it might inspire and make more sense to me.

I don't think it was as good as the first movie. But that is my opinion.

title: I am upset
review: They made the dragon way to small for what I was planning to see and I am also upset on how they made Legolas. He is suppose to be 60 years younger and looks so much older then He did in the lord of the rings. Have they never heard of make up? And going back to the dragon? He is buried under tons of gold but yet looks smaller then the dragon in "The Never Ending Story". I'm Sorry but there is something wrong with that. I was disappointed in the second Hobbit movie. If the last movie doesn't come out better I Believe it is going to ruin "The Hobbit" and "The Lord Of The Rings" trilogy together. There is also no way that Dragon could have flown after all that liquid gold was spilt all over him. I would have made his wings to weak to fly and gotten inside his wound and he wouldn't even want to move. All I can say is WOW!!!!!!!!!

title: A bad adaptation, but a good film
review:
The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, while definitely flawed and not up to the skill that The Lord of the Rings trilogy displayed, still served as a decent film adaptation of Tolkien's book (though three movies are a bit too stretched; two movies probably would have been enough; however, if the third movie delivers, then I won't complain too much). It did have some overuse of CGi and forced epic nature, but it wasn't the abomination that some detractors claimed it was (and neither was it the masterpiece that its most ardent fans said it was).

Now let me get to the plot summary: After the events of the previous film, the movie gives us a brief flashback to the events that happened before the journey, where Thorin (Richard Armitrage) is at an inn and Gandalf (Ian McKellen) meets him up there. It is here that Thorin is encouraged to go upon the quest and reclaim Erebor from the dragon Smaug (Benedict Cumberbatch). Later on, the film cuts to 12 months later, where Bilbo (Martin Freeman), Gandalf, Thorin and everyone else is on their journey and they come upon the house of Beorn (Mikael Persbrandt), in whose house they dwell while escaping from Azog and his forces. On the journey they encounter spiders, elves, and men, until they eventually come to the Lonely Mountain, to the Desolation of Smaug, and to their homeland in Erebor.

However, dark forces are awakening that were only hinted at before, and they will arise to cause great disaster that will threaten not only our characters but also the entire realm of Middle Earth.

Now that i got the plot summary out of the way, let me get to the actual review of the film.

Is it the superb and masterful sequel that some claim that it is? Is it the bloated abomination of epic proportions that the detractors claim? Or are these two options only two of many different views of this film.

The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug fails in many ways as an adaptation and rendition of the original source. While the main journey is there, much subplot has been added into the film (Thranduil, Legolas, and that female character Tauriel (Evangeline Lily)), and there is more CGi and more action than ever was in An Unexpected Journey. However, if one is considering this as a film, then for the most part this movie succeeds as a nice, exciting action flick that has some pretty good filmmaking and serves as a good blockbuster entertainment that doesn't transcend heights and genre limitations like Lord of the Rings did.

The acting is really good, with Ian McKellen and Martin Freeman doing really good jobs as Gandalf the Grey and Bilbo Baggins. Freeman really captures the development of Bilbo and how he has changed from the previous film. And McKellen captures the character of Gandalf as he learns of the evil that is awakening. Richard Armitrage as Thorin is well-acted, showing how the quest impacts Thorin's heart, changing him from a person concerned for Bilbo to a person almost mad for the Arkenstone and consumed by his desire for Erebor and the wealth it contains. Evangeline Lily is pretty decent as Tauriel, though I find her to still be filler that was added just to make the story more "female-friendly" (not to mention that I personally didn't connect with the implied love triangle with her, Legolas, and Kili, one of the thirteen dwarfs) and Orlando Bloom is also pretty good in his role as Legolas (though his face looks a bit unnatural in contrast to the Lord of the Rings movies). Benedict Cumberbatch was also good as Smaug, though not the master everybody claims he is

The script also is pretty good, but the film did drag a bit near the middle, especially with the overload of action sequences in this film, all of which are pretty good but which are not great. Many of the scenes border on over-the-top and popcorn-style scenes, with dwarfs suddenly having skills that rival the finest Olympic athletes, elves doing acrobatics while fighting evil monsters, Tauriel using cool ninja-style moves while killing monsters, and more. For the heavy action fan and an admirer of today's action-packed blockbuster entertainment, this movie is heaven. But for those who preferred Lord of the Rings and don't like overloaded action, this film will drag (even though I admit that I didn't hate most of the action scenes in the film). And may I note that this film has an excess of computer-generated images in contrast to the happy marriage of practical and digital effects that has existed in so many great films, masterpieces and classic movies of modern times (Jurassic Park, Terminator 2, and The Lord of the Rings trilogy, and many other films come to mind). While the CGi does manage to be good in the long run, there are instances where it looks fake, particularly in the ending where Thorin and all the dwarfs unleash a golden statue of a dwarf warrior and that statue melts and covers Smaug (the gold looked so laughably fake).

Overall, The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug, while a bit too overloaded with action and CGi as well as other pop-blockbuster elements of today, still serves as a nice action movie that both expands upon the merits of An Unexpected Journey and at the same time expands upon the demerits of the film. It works on the overall level as an action film set in Middle Earth, and despite its many flaws, there is just so much good work and effort put into this movie that it is near-impossible to compare this to other big-budget failures and punching-bags like the Star Wars prequel trilogy or Battlefield Earth.

It is not a perfect film, and neither is it a great film, but it is a good film. 3.5/5

title: Highly enjoyable thrilling romp through Middle Earth
review:
Peter Jackson continues his pursuit of bringing Middle Earth to the screen in as much detail as possible, with this the difficult middle film of the Hobbit trilogy.

The first Hobbit film received a solid if not spectacular critical reception, with some complaints about the long set up and just "too much singing". Box office of $1 billion plus, suggested critics had been too harsh.

This film has no need for lengthy exposition so we are straight into the action as the group continue their quest towards the Lonely mountain and a confrontation with a fire breathing talking dragon with a penchant for shiny treasure.

All the regular cast members are present and correct, the production values and costumes are as usual top notch. with special effects arguably the best in the world courtesy of Weta workshops, we are in safe hands here.

Having dispensed with big feasts and washing up malarkey, this time Bilbo (Freeman) gets to meet giant spiders, Elves, Lake dwellers, many, many Orc's and of course the titular Smaug guarding the treasure trove.

The dwarfs are again acted by well known faces, including Thorin (Richard Armitrage), Balin (Ken Stott) and Kilin (Aidan Turner) all made dwarf size through a combination of effects and simple perspective and camera tricks. Ian Mckellen of course takes on the Gandalf role and Orlando Bloom gets to do his hero, swashbuckling thing, dispensing Orcs, like he has never been away. Which of course is odd, as he has not reached the point where the LOTR Fellowship is even a consideration.

It is well known that Tolkien stinted on female characters, so Jackson and writers Walsh and Boyle neatly side step this omission by creating a feisty female Elf Tauriel (Evangeline Lilley), who is more than a match for Legolas. We even get a glimpse of romance and sexual tension with a possible, elf, dwarf love triangle in the offing.

Martin Freeman again anchors the enterprise with a comic yet human performance, it is difficult to imagine anyone playing this better. There are numerous action sequences including a thrilling barrel ride down a cascading river chased by despicable Orc's, with South Island NZ doubling beautifully for Middle Earth yet again.

Following the assistance of smuggler Girion (Luke Evans) we also get Stephen Fry as the leader of Lake town which seems an odd choice and arguably this sequence is weaker for this addition.

Overall a real return to form for director Jackson and the team, which places the series on firm ground for the final film. This is a rollicking adventure with thrills, spills, action, adventure and elements of humour whenever the going gets tough.

True, there are still many references to doom-laden scenarios that may mean little to non-Tolkien aficionado's but no matter, on whatever level you wish to approach the material, this is a resounding success.

Summary

Highly enjoyable thrilling romp through Middle Earth in company of the characters we have come to care about. This strips back some of the unnecessary fripperies and delivers on the original promise.

Highly recommended

Note** After watching both Hobbit 1 & 2 in 3D this will be the last time in that format. For this reviewer live action in 3D especially HFR, appears to expose the falseness of scenes. In future we will stay with 2D unless the whole film is CGI, where the true 3D benefits can be seen (i.e. Toy Story 3) - IMHO

title: Great Adventure & Contradictions
review: The Desolation continues the adventure with fights, shocks, humour and as usual great characters and fantastic scenery. Peter Jackson (appearing briefly on camera in Bree biting into a Carrot)has once again produced a masterpiece and yet? Wheareas the LOTR varied (as it had to) frequently from the book. The Hobbit: Desolation in particular bears little or no resemblance to the original story. Anyone hoping to tie this series in with LOTR should forget that notion. Both stories are excellent but there the relationship ends. Gandalf in this story is far more knowing about Saurons resurrection then he ever was in LOTR where his surprise at the extent of Saurons recovery (as told to him by Saroman) was very clear. While Sauron is gradually regaining his powers the Gandalf of LOTR would never have sought a direct confrontation with the evil one nor was that intended when he and his fellow wizards were sent to Middle Earth.I loved the film but to tell the truth it felt stretched. The scenes with Smaug were repeated over and over during the chase. Certain aspects were dragged out far longer than they needed to be. The Hobbit could and should have been made into two extended films but not three. That is only making it last for three movies harder. No doubt the final chapter will be great entertainment and I will enjoy it thoroughly its just that........?

title: alright
review: it was a OK flick but i did not like the ending and they show about 85% of the action in the previews i read the book and about the only thing alike is the title and the dragon never is even touched by a weapon he does get golded but it was a OK movie and gandelf pretty much just is a part time player also the bear king i forgot his name is a special appearance by person though legloas n his woman are a big part like i said it was OK but i did not like the ending at all it should have been called the hobbit and friends meet a lot of goblins and orcs and spiders also a few others along the way too a mountain ya know but the dragon smaug did look really good i have to say

title: Can't wait for the next instalment! 8/10
review:
Review: What an epic movie. I wasn't a big fan of The Lord Of The Rings movies and I thought that this movie was going to refer back to the other movies, but the storyline was pretty straight forward and easy to follow Gandalf explains the whole plot at the beginning so your able to enjoy the movie without trying to remember names and working out who is who. With that aside, Peter Jackson really did put together a movie spectacular, with fire breathing dragons, arrow shooting elves, ugly looking giant monsters and, of course, the harmless dwarfs. The whole film looked amazing, especially the attention to detail with the dragon, which looked believable. All of the sets looked great and there was a great mixture of characters which helped you along the two and a half hours epic. Anyway, this is a great movie which really does hype you up for the next instalment. Epic!

Round-Up: The way that the movie is advertised, I thought that it was going to be, mostly, about Bilbo Baggins and Gandolf, but it really does follows each character well and it doesn't concentrate any individual. Basically about a gang of dwarfs, fighting to claim back there kingdom but there are some elves and monsters thrown in to the mix. It was good to see Gandolf in his few scenes, but there isn't any Gollum, although you do hear his "Precious" every now and again. All of the characters put it great performances, which much have been hard because half of the characters are there to work with. The fighting scenes with the elves were excellent and very well choreographed. Honestly, I really haven't got a bad word to say about this film and I hope the next one is just as good or even better.

Budget: $250million Worldwide Gross: $950.5million

I recommend this movie to people who are into The Lord Of The Rings franchise which is full of adventure, fantasy and epic drama. 8/10

title: A very entertaining adventure into Middle Earth
review:
Positive: Dragon Smaug was awesome greatly crafted, new magical places of Middle Earth, Gandalf,Legolas,Bilbo,Thorin and the other company ,great action scenes, Sauron appearance

Negative: unnecessary scenes, bad romance ,bad CGI in some scenes

Following the Los Angeles premiere, Metro noted that early critical reaction was "glowing", with critics describing it as a "spectacle",[38] while The Guardian reported that it was receiving "much stronger early reviews".[39] However, before the film's theatrical release, E! reported that reviews had been "mixed", but stated they were still "much better" than the previous film.[40] After the film's international release, MTV reported that the film has garnered a "positive" critical reaction,[41] while the Los Angeles Times stated the consensus is that the film "reinvigorates" the series, putting it "back on course".[42] The review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes reported a 75% approval rating with an average rating of 6.9/10 based on 209 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "While still slightly hamstrung by "middle chapter" narrative problems and its formidable length, The Desolation of Smaug represents a more confident, exciting second chapter for the Hobbit series."[43] On aggregate review site Metacritic, the film has a score of 66 out of 100 based on 44 reviews, indicating "generally favorable" reviews.[44] According to CinemaScore polls the film received an "A-" from audiences.[45]

title: Definitely an improvement
review:
The Desolation of Smaug certainly improves over it's lacklustre-but-OK predecessor. I will say this for the movie, it boasts one of the most amazing CGI dragons that I have ever seen and some of the most rousing action that both builds suspense and moves along at a fun, swashbuckling pace. However, the film suffers from the same problems as the first film: there is just not enough plot to carry it's running time. When watching the film, one does sense a lot of needless subplots focused on characters that - no offence to them - we just don't care about. The Kili-Legolas-Tauriel love triangle for example, just doesn't hold enough interest. I will admit that long time fans will enjoy Legolas' appearance but it doesn't really add anything to a story that didn't contain the character in the first place. Another problem is that Gandalf barely gets any screen time in the already bloated movie, even though he is featured prominently on the poster. I know that Gandalf has a habit of leaving at random moments but come on, he could have been more central to the story.

On the light side, the visuals aren't nearly as disorientating as An Unexpected Journey, looks like Mr. Jackson has toned it down a bit. A high point for me was the barrel chase, which not only had some good visual effects but was an all round fun action scene. The cliffhanger also had me breathless. It was so beautifully orchestrated that it left me gasping to see There and Back Again. As for Ed Sheeran's "I See Fire" - I usually hate his music but his song ties up the movie perfectly, as does Howard Shore's trademark soundtrack. Overall, the film is a major improvement but is not without major flaws and I cannot wait to see what Jackson does with There and Back Again.

title: The hobbit sequel
review: After "The hobbit: an unexpected journey", the first part of the hobbit trilogy, the second movie is even more far away from the original story of the book. Don't get me wrong, it is very entertaining, just not what I expected. The story is the continuation of the first movie : Bilbo, the hobbit, in the company of 13 dwarfs and Gandalf the wizard are continuing their journey towards the lonely mountain and the stolen treasure, followed by a pack of orcs, attacked by elves and finally taking help from a human from the lake town. The special effects are brilliant, especially the dragon, who looks very real and horrible. The part when Sauron is taking the form of the eye in front of Gandalf wasn't that great, but I wasn't a fan of the idea of showing the Nekromad and his forces, from the beginning. Clever lines, not as funny as the ones from the first movie, but still very interesting. The love story between the elf and the dwarf was interesting too, surprisingly, as I believed, when I first heard of it being said by others who had already seen the movie, it will destroy the movie. The music was good too, epic and exciting, according to the mood of the film. The scenery was fantastic, gray and beautiful at the same time, especially that scene when Legolas is chasing the orc over the lake. All in all, a great movie, but not for the fans of the book, who will be disappointed if they expect the original story. P.S. The ending is a little bit sudden.

title: Loved the movie
review: I am lucky enough not to be a purist, who speaks elvish and can recite verbatim parts of the books. I did however read the Hobbit as a child and I must say I wasn't impressed, it was okay, maybe it was because I was a girl? Not sure. These movies however I love from beginning to the end. I am thrilled Peter Jackson is at the helm of these 3 Hobbit films. I was one who was thrilled that Jackson and the Lord of the Rings Films won the Oscar, in my opinion it deserved it. They are stunning stories, stories that keep me glued to the screen. When I am thinking of nothing but what is going on the screen you have captured me, its engrossing. I will again be very sad when this trilogy is over, I loved the first one and love this 2nd one. Wish Viggo Mortensen would of chosen to be in the film. Love the addition of Evangeline Lilly, and like an old friend loved seeing Legolas again! and the mention of Grimley, wonderful!

title: Entertaining if nothing else
review:
The Desolation of Smaug is a little less boring than the previous instalment, but it's really no better in terms of craft and narrative. Therere is one inspired action sequence in which the dwarfs and Bilbo escape from the elves in barrels. This sequence recalls Jackson's King Kong set pieces where he just builds ideas on top of ideas into an extended adventure. And that's it. Then it's all back to normal.

Whilst the Lord of the Rings were Oscar-winning technical marvels, the biggest issue I have with this and Journey is that the story is so mundane that we're left looking for a visual "wow" factor, and it's not there. The barrel sequence was so clever, I didn't care how the effects looked. The generic archery and dragon hunting wasn't creatively captivating, and it certainly wasn't visually so.

Overall it's entertaining and it's quite obvious the source material is so short that the crew had no choice but to embellish on the story. And add plenty of visual effects as filler to prolong this story across three films.

If you're seek an absolutely 100% accurate book to film translation you will be unhappy. But if you want to be entertained and can overlook this you'll have a nice time

title: The Saga continues...
review: I like sagas a lot, especially that ones which involve mythology, but I am not a huge fan of LORD OF THE RINGS. On the other hand, I am in love with THE HOBBIT. Since I watched THE HOBBIT – AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY in 2012, I have been astonished and became a fan immediately. What a fantastic movie! Some reviewers prefer to compare the book to the film. It is good to compare, however we must be careful. It is not right to say one is better than the other, because they have different kind of language. The screen players Fran Walsh, Philippa Boyens, Peter Jackson and Guillermo del Toro did an amazing work, they do not follow the book entirely neither frustrate who expect sees the book inside the film. It is possible to remember the scene of film when you are reading the book and vice-verse, even though they are not the same. The elf Legolas is one of the characters whose participation was a choice of the screen players, because he does not exist in the book yet. A great idea! Although I consider Orlando Bloom's career not as good as people thinks, but he has done a not bad job as Legolas since THE LORD OF THE RINGS. It is time to go the cast, officially! I have lots of things to say about this topic, but two words could embody everything: ABSOLUTELY FABULOUS! I am not going to analyse all of them, only three, because it would be an enormous review. It is clear as crystal that each actor and actress of this saga took his characters so serious and grew up with them. One of the actors does not need presentation: Ian Mckellen - a master in acting. He proves (he does not need to show anything, we know, we always knew) to be a perfectionist in every single scene. Martin Freeman - known by playing Watson in SHERLOCK (TV) – is a great actor, I have to confess I am a big fan of Sherlock and admire so much Martin in his work on TV, his performance never disappoint me. Richard Armitage (our King under the mountain) is another nice choice, he is really good at. I am pretty sure he is the tallest dwarf I have ever seen in my whole life, he became a giant in dwarf skin in minutes, if you know what I mean. There is an especial scene that I picked up to you just for you feel the vibe of the film: Bilbo surfing on the Dragon's fortune, or better, Bilbo sliding on the Smaug's treasure. It is unforgettable! Well, I don not want to stop writing, it is so many things that it should be said, but this review must end , so I finish it now and leave a tip for you: If you are addicted to elf, orc, sorcerer, wizard, dwarf, hobbit, enchanted mountain, duel, sword an many more strange creatures, run to the movies right now, it is an order!!!!!

title: Entertaining but just not a great addition to the Middle Earth universe
review:
"The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug" feels all too familiar, because it is. Peter Jackson pretty much uses up all his tropes to breathe life into this unnecessary middle part of the trilogy based on a story that's been stretched too thin already.

The story picks up where the first Hobbit film left off, but it is a much darker film. Even the sprightly Bilbo Baggins has a certain nastiness to him, add to that the Necromancer, Mirkwood, and a new Orc Chieftain you have a grim tale to tell, but that's where Peter Jackson's latest effort comes up short. There is no tale to tell and the film, in a self-parodying fashion ends up being a walkathon.

New characters like Evangeline Lily's Tauriel are nice additions, but it all feels like filler especially when Jackson strays from source material with clichéd dialogue, contrived romances and predictable action sequences. Speaking of which, the stakes were never lower for our traveling company. There is no orc nor Morgul blade that the dwarfs and the surprisingly efficient Bilbo cannot overcome and if you rolled your eyes at the Goblin cave sequence in the first film, be prepared for more of the same in this one.

Unsurprisingly, the production quality is top-notch and so is the music. The dragon - Smaug is very well crafted and voiced by Benedict Cumberbatch. The film, while long at over 160 mins involving mainly walking around, never feels boring. It just isn't a great addition to the Middle Earth universe and feels like a filler. But it does succeed in building up anticipation for the grand finale. 6.5/10

title: Not a Tolkien fanatic.
review:
A love a good fantasy novel and a great movie, but I have never been one to worship in the church of Tolkien; I've read the three volumes of Lord of the Rings and consider him a master storyteller, but they hardly changed my life and frankly after all these decades, these books really show their age.

I am a huge fan of Peter Jackson's LOTR trilogy, maybe the finest work of movie fantasy next to STAR WARS and THE MATRRIX, so there was no way I would miss Jackson's version of THE HOBBIT. In my view, THE HOBBIT makes a good movie, but it's probably better if the viewer has not read Tolkien's original story, which is after all, a rather slim (by LOTR standards) children's book. While AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY set things up with a lot of introduction and exposition, THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG, lets the action rip, as the band of dwarfs, along with Bilbo Baggins and Gandalf race toward the Lonely Mountain and their eventual encounter with the fierce dragon, Smaug.

Lots and lots of liberties with the book have been taken as it was expanded to a three part epic. This has brought down upon Jackson and company the wrath of the church of Tolkien, who are quite vocal about such blasphemies as having the elf Legolas appear in the movie, when he doesn't in the book. That, along with a romance, seem to have driven the Hobbit devotees up the wall and across the ceiling.

They need to understand that any movie version of any literary work is simply a version of the story set in an alternate universe: it's the same characters, but they may well be doing different things. Just enjoy the ride for what it is. That is way Stephen King explained the changes made in UNDER THE DOME when it was adapted for CBS television.

For me, THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG contained the kind of great set piece scenes we go to the movie theater to see in the first place, especially the battle between the dwarfs and the Orcs as the former attempt to flee by floating down a river in barrels. Then there is Bilbo's climatic encounter with Smaug under The Lonely Mountain, a great use of CGI in combination with Benedict Cumberbatch's vocal contributions. Not to mention the encounter with the spiders in Mirkwood. All well worth the price of a ticket; and again all very different from the book.

There are a lot of things wrong with THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG: the pacing is uneven as the running time is stretched to nearly three hours; it's still hard to keep track of who is who among the band of dwarfs other than Thorin the leader; some of the romance is clearly just shoe horned into the story; a truly abrupt ending that leaves way too many loose threads; what's with Evnangeline Lilly's way too large Elf ears? And why does Thorin turn on Bilbo at one point, thus negating the moving final scene of AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY.

Still Peter Jackson does an magnificent job of creating a fantasy world that lives and breathes, a place that has a lot of history. Same with many of the characters, such as Lee Pace's Thandril, the Elf King, whom we sense have stories in their past that would make for an epic movie all by themselves. That goes for Ian McKellen's Gandalf, the original wise old wizard; it's great to see him back in the role that, along with Magneto, made him famous to millions worldwide. Martin Freeman, as Bilbo, more than holds his own against the other great talent on the screen. But I miss Christopher Lee's Sauromon and there is only a brief glimpse of Cate Blanchett's Galadriel.

So enjoy the movie for what it is, then read the book and do the same.

title: Great Contiuation from the 1st movie...
review: The Hobbit: Desolation of Smaug carries on after our crew of Dwarfs and Bilbo are picked up by the Eagles. While the way the group meet Beorn isn't exactly like the it is in the book, it was interesting and keeps the continuity from the first film. I do like how they revealed the true identity of the Necromancer, and the addition of Legolas to the cast although he is never mentioned in the book. He is the only one that could have been around when this story played out, and of course is the son of the Elven king. Peter Jackson is doing a great job with the Hobbit Trilogy just as he did with the Lord of the Rings Trilogy. I can't wait to see the extended additions of these films to see the book better incorporated into the Movie. I highly recommend this Movie to all fans of Middle Earth.

title: Jackson's vision is a departure from Tolkien
review:
Unlike many other reviewers, I do not fault Peter Jackson merely because he departs from his literary source. A film is not a book. Jackson has a right to take wide latitude from the original to create his own vision of this or any other story. This being established,

I found this film to be a whole lot of fun and adventure! Yes, there are large differences between Tolkien and Jackson's telling of this story. But I believe those who detract from his films merely on this account are woefully short-sighted.

Jackson is making a small children's book into a massive epic retelling of monumental events in Middle-Earth history. Do the math; you can't get three immense films out of one small children's story book without cooking up some major inflations of Tolkien's quaintly narrated events.

LOTR is adult literature, but The Hobbit is not. Therefore the transformations involved in getting from book to cinema must of necessity be much more extreme. This accounts for most of Jackson's augmentations in the Hobbit films.

Another consideration is that this segment of Hobbit is much richer than the first. How can anyone fault him for ramping up the action sequences involving Beorn, giant spiders, the Necromancer, and Smaug? It would have been a waste to portray all those sequences on the quaint level of Tolkien's original narrative.

The one major detraction I cite Jackson for is all this nonsense about Tauriel and Kili. I understand that in cinema, romance is an essential element that needs to be included (but I still don't like it in the context of Tolkien!). But the concept of an Elf romantically attracted to a dwarf (and vise-versa) is thoroughly unacceptable! It would never happen in Tolkien, and it should never be countenanced in any film version of his works! But the effrontery does not merely stop there! The most shameful affront is the salacious banter between Kili and Tauriel about "what he might have in his trousers!" That is an inglorious disgrace that should never be tolerated in these adaptations! I hope Jackson has the good sense to eliminate or at least tone-down this plot thread in the final installment!

The other major departures to found in Desolation of Smaug are thoroughly excusable and mostly even improvements, in my opinion.

The barrel sequences actually make more sense than the original. The idea that elves would ignore that fact that barrels that should be empty are filled with something very heavy always bothered me in the original story. Jackson solved this in his version by having Bilbo launch the barrels himself. I also often wondered how dwarfs could be expected to survive in water-tight sealed barrels as they drifted through freezing river streams. Jackson solves this problem by keeping the barrels unsealed. I thoroughly enjoyed the barrel sequences, as over-the-top as it indeed is! The scene with Bombor's barrel bouncing around among the orcs is an absolute hoot! I laughed out loud through the whole thing! The battle sequences in this part were also far- fetched, but I found them a great romp of fun as well. Jackson loves to show off the battle prowess of elves, and I find this thoroughly in keeping with Tolkien's vision of the Eldar.

The dragon scenes, as extremely inflated and changed as they are, are also understandable to my mind. Why waste a perfectly good dragon by sticking to the constructs of Tolkien's children's narrative? It would have been a disservice to do less than Jackson did.

I must admit that at first the purist in me balked at seeing Bilbo visible to Smaug and the dwarfs running from Smaug inside Erebor, but I soon realized that it made perfect sense unless you were going to make the whole interior of the mountain one simple pitch black treasure chamber as Tolkien did. But such a decision on Jackson's part would have been contrary to the best qualities of the cinematic media. In the days when special effects were best only hinted at because they were too transparent to appear authentic it may have been justified, but when you have the full gamut of seamless effects at your disposal, why not take everything to the limit? After all, it's doubtful that this film franchise will ever be duplicated in the future, and Jackson, for all his excellent qualities as a filmmaker, has never cultivated the reputation of being a minimalist! perhaps someday a purist version of Hobbit and LOTR will be filmed, but I'm not holding my breath, nor do I recommend it to others!

All in all, I found this installment mostly satisfying along with bright hopes for the concluding segment next year. My one fear is that Jackson will insist on ending the story with an ill-advised wedding scene between Kili (who should by rights die in the battle of the 5 armies!) and Tauriel (MAJOR GAG! MAJOR CRINGE!)

title: If I had known better words than 'amazing' I'd use it.
review: After the unexpected boring journey of the first of the Hobbit Trilogy, I thought that, the series is going to be useless. But this Hobbit proved me wrong. I have absolutely no words how to describe it. It's really good. What to praise? The visual effects? or the graphics? or should it be the way everything is presented? I have got no idea. But to be honest, I really really enjoyed watching the movie. It's a long movie but for me, it ended too fast. Everyone did their best job. I had no time finding flaws in the movie, or say, I just ignored them. The movie is worth viewing. No doubt, the continuation of "Lord of the Rings Series" has maintained its level.

title: My Only Two Problems with this film
review:
I loved this movie and the previous, even with all the mistakes and goofs throughout. But before I go into those, I thoroughly enjoy Peter Jackson's version of the Hobbit since I have read it several times before the first movie was actually in consideration of being made. So I grew up with Tolkien's stories and playing AD&D for many years.

I have high expectations of Peter Jackson and he did very well with the first movie, An Unexpected Journey. More expectations were set before going to see The Desolation of Smaug, and again - Peter Jackson did a superb job of giving me a great experience. With a couple exceptions, and here I go with those Issues I have...

This movie has only two major problems with me. The First, Orlando Bloom's face is CGI'd and given bright blue eyes. In the previous trilogy, Orlando Bloom was not CGI'd at all and his blue eyes were darker.

So there is a huge difference between Legolas of the Hobbit and Lord of the Rings, and anyone who knows Elves --- they don't change since they are immortal.

And then of course the ending. The ending sucked! And that's all I have to say about the Desolation of Smaug. Be Safe Out There!

title: Not the saga's best, but still a great movie
review:
If you like the saga you will like this movie a lot. If you are not a fan of fantasy worlds, you won't like it as much but it's still a movie worth watching.

One dilemma I have with these movies is their running time. I always think they could have been broken down into several shorter episodes and be much more enjoyable than the 3-hour movies they turn out to be.

This particular segment of the Hobbit's story is more transitional than the previous and the next, so the viewer might feel the beginning and the ending of the movie are lacking in "introduction" and "closure". This is why I argue the movie doesn't need to be that long, since the director is cutting it wherever anyhow.

The special effects are absolutely outstanding and the action scenes are incredibly dynamic and original. The music is always beautiful, and wardrobe and make-up are as good as it gets.

Character development is given less importance in this title compared to the rest of the trilogy, and the storyline is more focused on the adventure itself. There's a few new colorful characters, but, again, not greatly developed just yet in the saga.

It is, all in all, a great movie to watch, specially in theaters. The problem is that we can't help but to compare it to the other Lord of the Rings titles, which are overall, in my opinion, better than this one.

title: Overextended eye-candy
review: Peter Jackson continues smearing the 'Hobbit' out over another 2 hour and 41 minute sandwich. There is just not enough happening, they linger to long on nonessential scenes, there is too much dialogue without adding much content. It feels a bit like the Star Wars prequels: it's made by the same skillful people but it's just not as good as the original, there's something missing. What the film is very good at is serving up pure eye-candy. The attention to detail in the costumes, props, sets and VFX is mind-boggling. Howard Shore again provides the score but besides hints of the LOTR theme it's just not that memorable. If you've seen the other LOTR films you're not gonna skip this one so I don't need to convince anyone I guess. I just hope they don't make an extended version for the Blu Ray because this one already feels overextended as it is...

title: Very good, not lord of the rings quality though
review:
I'll be the first to say when these films were announced I has no hope that they would be anywhere near as good as The Lord of the rings and they aren't. That said they are still good and Martin Freeman plays the role perfectly.

I liked this film a lot but although it followed the events of the book I think it should've followed how those events happened more closely. That being said everything else was very good and I especially like Benedict cumberbatches dragon who I thought felt very real. Also I liked Orlando blooms character as he made It feel slightly more like The Lord of the rings trilogy.

title: A Slight Improvement on An Unexpected Journey
review:
The film rattles along and there is much smiting. This is good. There is much that is not good in this over inflated vanity project.

The Lord Of The Rings trilogy was brilliant and memorable, because it brought a classic story to life. It's a long story, and the films were necessarily long too.

It is outrageous of Peter Jackson to think that his own plot lines might improve upon the author's. In fifty years, will people still be talking about how the brilliant Peter Jackson made the Hobbit an even better story, as well as a good film?

When this film trilogy is complete, it will take you longer to watch it than to read the book, which is both daft and self indulgent. Someone should have told the Director that his hubris was ruining the project.

title: Peter Jackson's Hobbit
review: This is a good film - but it's not as magical as the LOTR. It feels like it's gone a bit to PJ's head. That he has full liberty to change whatever he wants to increase the length of the story. eg. - you have Orlando Bloom and Evangeline Lilly fighting orcs in Lake Town, or to put it another way 2 made-up characters (a female to create female interest/a love triangle and Orlando just because PJ likes him / thinks the fans like him) fighting orcs that were never in the book until the end. The barrel ride in the book had Bilbo on top of sealed barrels quietly floating down the river to Lake Town. Bilbo opens the lid after 2 days to find some very grumpy dwarfs. Here we have open barrels, a 20minute action scene featuring the above 2 elf characters and more orcs. LOTR changed some things but often to fit it all into 3x 3 films - this is the opposite and on a whole new level! Also the editing to keep cutting to Gandalf's scenes halfway through Bilbo, the dwarfs and the dragon fight reminded me of Return of the Jedi's climax - but ROTJ was a perfect edit. Here it's really ham fisted cutting right in the middle of a chase scene. In ROTJ they cut when there was a convenient quiet point (Luke hides/rests, them big doors closing on Endor, the space attack failing). Here it's just jarring. Also, in the back of people's mind is the fact Gandalf journeyed for weeks to get there so it seems so badly edited to even construe that all of this is happening at the same time. Also, in ROTJ the storeys influenced each other (turning off that energy shield). Here the storey's aren't relevant to each other - at least within the context of the film. It's a mess. Really disappointed how this trilogy is panning out PJ. Some fan boys and people that haven't read the book will rave about the wonderful orcs and action - but that's not the book. Save it all for the final battle in film 3.

title: Ridiculing, Cheap, but Entertaining
review:
The theater in which I saw The Hobbit: Desolation of Smaug seated over 300 people and it was completely filled, not an empty seat in the house. What did that cause? Humidity, claustrophobia, and distractions. The viewing experience mirrored the film we were watching. Though it improves from the first chapter, The Hobbit Desolation of Smaug feels suffocating and prolonged, the tone becomes an object of ridicule (who knew the legacy of the-end-of- the-world trilogy that was Lord of the Rings would be reduced to the unserious nature of The Hobbit trilogy?), and extremely cheap (remember when Fellowship of the Ring won Best Cinematography, clearly Desolation of Smaug forgot).

The film does benefit from the short-lived presence of Gandalf played magnificently by Ian McKellen, but even his lines have evolved from deep thoughtfulness to reactions of slapstick comedy. McKellen has a charm as Gandalf that Marlon Brando created with The Godfather that soothes the viewer, that is what makes these characters iconic.

The hours of set building, CGI construction of Smaug, costume designing, and make-up work seek through the emaciated screenplay and the farce tone. If There and Back Again retains the same tonal treatment, maybe the studios should submit it to the Golden Globes as a Comedy/Musical with a nostalgic campaign of the original trilogy

Grade: C+

Rating: 5

title: Peter Jackson's done it again... brilliant but long
review:
The second installment in the Hobbit story had a lot to live up to, first in terms of The Lord of the Rings, and secondly The Unexpected Journey. This sees the band of dwarfs and Bilbo (with ring) get to The Lonely Mountain to try and claim it back from Smaug the dragon. They go via Mirkwood and so we meet the elves and get introduced to Legolas (Orlando Bloom, who's a little less elf-sylph-like around the face in this one...) Adventure and fun ensues. There's orc-slaying a-plenty with a never ending supply of elvish arrows in the quiver, a barrel of laughs as dwarfs make a getaway and lots of dwarvish physical humour especially at the expense of the fat dwarf and I always get a giggle from Nesbitt's antics and his silly hat (Bofur, the dwarf). Even Stephen Fry does an almost unrecognisable star turn in this film as the hideous Master of the Lake Town. Richard Armitage (Thorin) has the most acting range, possibly, in terms of the adventure-party and his voice caries the gravitas of his Dwarf-King-in-Waiting status. There's a little romance, which is rather touching, but the star of the show is Smaug the dragon, beautifully realised and brilliant CGI - flawless. Wizard Gandalf (Sir Ian McKellan) has a relatively small role in this film, which is a shame but he does do some fierce battle with Sauron/the Necromancer. However, the main (non CGI) star I think is Martin Freeman as Bilbo; I love his little gestures and comedic timing and characterisation of the Hobbit, especially when he's in a quandary.

Once again the special effect that allows hobbits and dwarfs to stand short next to men is really clever and I struggle to get used to seeing familiar (tall) actors made to look small but that is dwarfed (pardon the pun) by all the CGI which I really do get tired of, although it was less in your face and obvious than the last film; I realise it is necessary but sometimes it LOOKS less convincing. Overall this is enjoyable, accomplished and an entertaining part of the overall story for a Middle Earth fan, and it has all the elements you would want from a Hobbit story. I haven't read the book for a long LONG time so can't remember how close it sticks to the book but much of it rang bells. No matter, I know it was done by a fan of Tolkien and someone who would want to do it justice (note Peter Jackson's cameo in the opening scene) and he's done an excellent job. Again. I think I preferred the story of the first and it was more exciting (gripping/suspenseful) but this was a better film and the SFX were largely better. I preferred the first one over all in terms of opinion coming away, as I felt this one dragged a bit and got a bit bogged down, and it could have been shorter.

For this film to make sense, I imagine you'd have needed to see the first of the films. Not a film for arachnophobes, as an aside.

title: Good movie but works as part of a series rather than stand-alone
review: The special effects were good. It has a lot of action in it. It's part of the series and the plot doesn't really work as a stand-alone movie. It's open-ended so it's a bit disappointing. Gandalf goes off on an adventure of his own and intends to meet Bilbo and the dwarfs later but doesn't. Bilbo goes into the mountain to retrieve the Arkenstone but doesn't manage to get it and tells the dwarfs this, but then nobody says anything further about the matter. They all battle the dragon in a very long fight scene but are unable to defeat it and it flies off to attack the town. It would have worked better as a stand-alone movie if the adventurers (erroneously) believed that they had killed the dragon, and if they retrieved the Arkenstone, and Gandalf then rejoined them to celebrate.

title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug
review: The first film of the three part prequel series to The Lord of the Rings Trilogy based on the famous J.R.R. Tolkien books, from returning director Peter Jackson and writer Guillermo Del Toro, was good and established the characters well, and naturally I was excited to see the next part. Basically after the opening, seeing how Gandalf the Grey (Sir Ian McKellen) recruited dwarf Thorin Oakenshield (Richard Armitage) to join a fellowship to reclaim the dwarfs' lost kingdom of Erebor, the story continues where the last left off, where hobbit Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman), Gandalf, Thorin and the rest of the dwarfs, Balin (Ken Stott), Dwalin (Graham McTavish), Fíli (Dean O'Gorman), Kíli (Being Human's Aidan Turner), Dori (Mark Hadlow), Nori (Jed Brophy), Ori (Adam Brown), Óin (John Callen), Glóin (Peter Hambleton), Bifur (William Kircher), Bofur (James Nesbitt) and Bombur (Stephen Hunter) have crossed over (and under) the Misty Mountains. They are chased by orcs and find shelter in the house of skin-changer Beorn (Mikael Persbrandt), and after Gandalf leaves the company the other continue into Mirkwood, following the instruction that they must stay on the path, of course this becomes difficult, and giant spiders slow them in their tracks, but Bilbo with his sword he names Sting and the help of elves Tauriel (Evangeline Lilly) and Legolas (Orlando Bloom), son of Elven King Thranduil (Lee Pace), defeat these foes. The elves put the group into cages, but Bilbo using the One Ring he took from Gollum releases them, and at the riverbank they meet bowman Bard (Luke Evans) who for a price agrees to smuggle them on his barge of barrels into Lake-town, where they hope to find a range of better weapons before they reach the Lonely Mountain, where the feared dragon Smaug (Benedict Cumberbatch) lays waiting, but of course the company are unwelcome by the Master of Lake- town (Stephen Fry). After agreeing that they will give the town a high amount of the riches from inside the cave of the dragon, and some other little bits and pieces of argument or fighting, they are allowed to continue on, and eventually they reach the top of the Lonely Mountain, and Bilbo decodes the message of the wall of how to open the door, and he as the "burglar" is the one that must enter the dragon's lair and find the Arkenstone. Gandalf meanwhile travelled with fellow wizard Radagast (Sylvester McCoy), but he is alone in the orc-ambushed Dol Guldur, where he engages with the dark evil called the Necromancer (also Cumberbatch), but his true identity is revealed, it is in fact the evil force of the dark lord Sauron, returned to Middle Earth, and after battle the wizard ends up captured. Bilbo clambers his way into the caves, and through the millions of golden treasures and jewels, looking amongst them for the distinctive Arkenstone, of course he cannot escape waking Smaug, the large dragon may not be able to see him with the ring on, but he senses his presence, and the hobbit does his best to convince him he is not stealing anything, but ultimately the dwarfs come to save him when the situation becomes too dangerous. They manage to trick Smaug into using his fiery breath for opposite effect, and they think they have killed him by drowning him in a a vat of molten gold, but in fact he shakes this off, and in rage the dragon escapes the mountain and starts flying towards Lake-town, Bilbo watches as the beast makes his way to wreak havoc, and in devastation all he can say is "what have we done?", this is the cliffhanger. Also starring Cate Blanchett as Galadriel, Ryan Gage as Alfrid and Lawrence Makoare as Makoare. Freeman still remains likable as the slowly becoming confident and reliable hero, McKellen is still wonderful as the wise wizard prepared to do anything to protect his shorter friend, and many of the supporting cast members bring a little something to their characters, but best, as he is so unrecognisable, is the voice of Cumberbath as dragon Smaug, he is so dark and booming, it is admittedly not as sweeping as The Lord of the Rings Trilogy was, but the special effects are still amazing, the scene between Bilbo and Smaug is the most engaging part, and there are the action packed sequences to keep you happy, a most worthwhile fantasy adventure. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Sound Editing, Best Sound Mixing and Best Visual Effects, and it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Make Up/Hair and Best Special Visual Effects. Good!

title: Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger
review: This year's biggest (literally) pleasant surprise. After the long, slow start to chapter one had dampened the ardour of many a Middle Earth fan, I had more modest hopes for what could be achieved eking out yet another three hour behemoth from the middle chapters of Tolkien's modest children's tale and Peter Jackson has exceeded every one magnificently. Bold, energetic, funny, frightening, tense, and immensely spectacular. The clear aim now is to take The Hobbit as a skeleton structure that will be fleshed with all the immense back-story, parallel tales and grim foreshadowing of what is to come that it can withstand. It's a brave, and somewhat indulgent move, but it's coming together here with a bravura confidence that was sometimes lacking from part one. This is now just a dwarf's whisker from Lord Of The Rings greatness.

title: Good movie of the book, not worse than other LotR movies
review: Follows the book almost all the time. Peter Jackson put a little love story in it, while the book barely has any female characters at all. Orlando Bloom has a little place in it as well as Legolas, we can see a new Legolas, why he became what he was in the Lord of the Rings, why he hates dwarfs so much. Actors and actresses play well, Peter Jackson did a great job in directing this movie as well. Big LotR fans will love this movie as well, though some people might start to find this movie a bit long with a bit too much repeating throughout the movies. All of all I give it an eight. I like LotR and this was a great movie as well, recommend it to everyone, even if you haven't seen the Lord of the Rings itself, for after all the Hobbit is before the Lord of the Rings in time.

title: It was good.
review: It was definitely good. I loved the visual effects. The story was good, it made me want more and more. It also made me wonder how long I was going to watch the movie for because two hours passed and they (the main characters) were still no where near to where they wanted to be. The ending was unexpected, I didn't know the ending was the ending, and neither did the people in the theater too. We sat there for a good few minutes in darkness wondering if that was it until the credits started rolling. I wished it had more of an ending, but what can I say, there must be another part to this movie coming. There is still a lot to this story to be continued and truths to be told. Overall an 8.5, not 10 because of the ending, it left me at a cliffhanger.

title: While I miss Frodo...I am enjoying Bilbo!
review:
The adventure continues and just like the Lord of the Rings, Two Towers, this "middle" movie kinda leaves you unsatisfied. Mostly because you know what is just around the corner! Maybe two movies could have been better, as in LOTR, but if you love these movies you put up with the "middles" and feeling unsatisfied a bit! Martin Freeman (Bilbo) continues to carry this character just fine. I had my doubts at first but when I saw The Hobbit, I was sold. He IS Bilbo Baggins now just as Elijah Wood IS Frodo. The other actors play their parts exceedingly well, too. Will anyone ever be able to re-make these movies with others? I think NO unless they wait a generation or so.

As a reader of the books, I see that many small, rather important details are left out mostly due to necessity of time restraints. And to me this does not take away from the enjoyment of the story. Although, IMO, there are more missing details from the Hobbit tales than from LOTR. Again, this does not take away from my enjoyment of the flicks.

I love that Orlando Bloom (Legolas) is still doing great skateboarding-type moves, too. I cracked up at that. The addition of Evangeline Lilly is perfect as she is as much an Elf-like beauty as Liv Tyler. All the actors including the usual suspects (Ian, Richard, Andy, etc.) do a stellar job in portraying their fantasy characters. An enjoyable ride through Middle Earth...

title: Better than the first..
review: This film was never going to be equivalent to the Lord of the Rings, yet unfortunately that is why I have found fault in it. The epic scales of LOTR could never be matched in the Hobbit, and though the second adventure of the dwarfs did increase in action and thrilling suspense, with Smaug's presence being graciously welcomed, it feels far too childish in comparison to LOTR. Perhaps my growing tastes have influenced my review, in that growing up with LOTR and growing older tastes when the Hobbit was released meant I couldn't appreciate it with the same fervour a child would. However it feels that these films seem to garner a lot more humour, and lack the subtlety with which was found in LOTR, not that this is a bad thing, some viewers might find the light heartedness necessary, but for me I feel it detracts from the story. Once again, this film feels like it is lengthened unnecessarily, and the source material extrapolated to create a far more expansive universe than there should be, at a push this could be a duology, not a trilogy.

title: Pack your family and go fight the the spiders
review:
The first move (Unexpected Journey) was kinda ruined for me, because I watched in HFS and came out of the theatre, with my eye balls rolling in different directions (yeah, like a chameleon). I felt that movie was bit dragged. So, this time, I watched "Desolation of Smaug" in 2D.

Man, It was wonderful. I was sitting at the edge of the seat nibbling my finger nails throughout the whole movie (eh except for those romantic scenes: oh gross). I have read the book and I can say that the plot is kinda 60% goes with the book. However, those modifications add a lot of value to the movie (eh, except for the romantic scenes : It felt like the "Madagascar" love scene between the giraffe and hippo: "unnatural" )

Overall, it is a movie full of adventure and action and could be considered a fantastic entertainer to end your year with, even if you have read the book already.

title: Spiders? Run! Orcs? Run! Dragon? Run! Sure was a lot of running here...
review:
"The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug" is actually the best of all the movies in the Lord of the Rings universe. Well, at least I think so. "The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey" was nice, but "The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug" is just a tad better, and especially better than the movies in the first trilogy.

The characters in the movie, are unfortunately, much as in the previous movie, where only two-three of the dwarfs are actually given time on the screen and show that they are more than mere extras. It is a shame, because all thirteen dwarfs would have something individual and unique to bring to the movie aside from just being extras and fillers.

There is a lot of running in this movie. Basically the movie is one long chase. The group are chased by spiders, they run; they are chased by orcs, they run; they are chased by a dragon, they run. Despite all this cat and mouse chasing, then the 161 minutes the movie runs for come and go in the blink of an eye.

This is indeed a movie with special effects, and there is nothing spared. There has been paid a lot of attention to the effects, and it has really paid off nicely. The spiders were really interesting and nicely animated, well aside from the talking that is. And Smaug himself and his vast hoard of treasure and trinkets, well that makes it worth watching the movie for that alone.

If you enjoy sword and fantasy, then of course you are familiar with the work of Tolkien. But translating a relative small book into a movie in three parts? Well, there is a lot of fillers, surely, but so far it is working out nicely enough. Perhaps not having read Tolkien's books is actually in your favor. Just enjoy the movies for the high fantasy that it is and don't pay too much attention to how true (or not) the movies are to the books.

As for the people on the cast list, well the casting department has done a nice job, as usual.

And as it was with the previous four movies, then it is grand to see the places brought to life, especially after having spent numerous years of playing Lord of the Rings Online.

"The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug" is great fun, an adventure for just about everyone.

title: I like the total series of LOTR
review:
Hi, I am fancylive and I love the series of LOTR...I mean from start to the last one " The hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)..And that's ultimately what The Desolation of Smaug is. No beginning, no end, lots of middle. To that end, I suspect one's affinity for this installment will correlate directly with how much of a mark the preceding film made. Beginning with a flashback (within the flashback that is the entire trilogy), we learn how Ian McKellen's wizard Gandalf first crossed paths with princely dwarf Thorin Oakenshield (Richard Armitage) in the lead-up to this saga's central quest, retrieving a lost gem that rightly belongs to the dwarfs from the dragon Smaug. From there, we rejoin our band of dwarf questers, and the titular Hobbit whose story we're ostensibly following, Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman).

Whether outrunning giant wolves, outwitting giant spiders, or outthinking slightly tall elves, Smaug is essentially one long chase sequence punctuated by conversations as it ticks down to the title's promised conflagration. In that sense it marks a slight step up from its predecessor, given that An Unexpected Journey was saddled with a treasure trove of exposition and explication that's largely unnecessary here. And so we get an experience that, at it's best, engages on a visual, sensory level. The returning cast is still great, and it's also nice to see Orlando Bloom return as his Rings hero Legolas, the elf archer (although his role here is largely extraneous).

Where the film falls down, then, is exactly where the first one did. It's simply too much time spent servicing too little. I've made note before of how Tolkien's original tome is a breezy 300-page confection, and the miscalculation the adaptation makes, under Jackson's auspices, is in trying to take those 300 pages and spin them into a nine-hour behemoth. Now, part of this is simply the seams between "art" and "commerce" showing through. The various stakeholders in the Hobbit screen rights fought the equivalent of their own "War of the Ring" to see the book brought to screen, so they were damn sure going to squeeze every last dollar out of it they could.

And why make one flick, or even two, when you can just as well make three movies, and three times the coin? After all, there were three hugely-successful Lord of the Rings movies, right? Naturally. But what's seemingly been forgotten is that, for as mammoth a production as the Rings trilogy was, and for as long as the individual entries ended up being, each movie adapted one book. Only one book. Thus, in the process of spinning prose into celluloid, lots of little digressions and details got left out in service of the all-important need to maintain the pace and propulsion necessary to make a worthwhile filmic experience.

With the Hobbit movie series, on the other hand, we have an entirely different set of problems brought about by the decision (command?) to expand Tolkien's relatively lightweight book outward times three. Put simply, there's simply not enough story to make the process work feasibly. And so Jackson, et al, have been forced to forage through the various appendices, sidelights, assumptions, and implications that Tolkien peppered his various Middle Earth works with to pad, pad, pad out the running time and get us to that preordained 160-minute mark (with 160 more yet to come twelve months hence).I like all the character of these movies.... outstanding one...thanks for bringing on,,hats of ptv sports live, The main character I missing allot..but anyway this is the way how its going on

regards Fancylive

title: A TV series atmosphere
review:
Jackson, fortunately and unfortunately, set the bar high with his sequel trilogy of "Lord of the Rings".

Here, we have a story that probably 95% of this present day generation know about, and about a third know almost every detail, so we're actually dealing with a "rendition" of a "fairy tale" in ways.

First of all, many characters, notably Gandalf, Bilbo, and Legolas, are household words, and are known to appear in the sequel.

There may come a day, fifty years from now, when half the people will not know this, and may see these "prequels" first, but even then, it will be very well known. We know these certain characters will survive, just as TV regular characters survive.

So, it appears that Jackson is giving these certain characters an "observer" effect, much like Eastwood in HANG EM HIGH and Burr's added in character in GOZILLA.

These characters are like the "stable" personalities of TV series title characters, who observe what guest stars do. One could say that Gandalf is Columbo, Bilbo is Sugarfoot, Legolas is Bronco, and so forth.

This story is the second of a trilogy, which is usually the action packed one with less direction. However, here, we have direction with less accomplishments.

I don't think it's a spoiler to let people know that the resolution with the dragon comes first, and then the huge war. I was disappointed that this film didn't end with the resolution with the dragon, and save the war for last.

That is the way Jackson deviates from the usual pattern. He is using this entire film to "lead up" to further events. Almost nothing is resolved here, and many subplots are laid in store for the final.

It is a very good film, but the bar is high on these films, and I wanted more. I have no problem with the added bits, like the she elf romance. At first, I thought it was a mistake to make Legolas so important, because we know he's in no danger, but it appears to be Jackson's way of saying that he doesn't want his "fate" to interfere with the story, and that he wants us to observe with him.

Radagast makes a brief appearance, but he is purposely made into a cameo character here, as if to downplay him. For those who missed the "Unexpected Journey", there was a definite symbolism accorded to Gandalf and Radagast as members of a bygone generation, with Gandalf representing the sixties and early seventies hippie movement, the pot smoking activists, and Radagast symbolic of the younger brother of Gandalf, the child of the late seventies, lost as a rebel without a cause.

The ineffectiveness of Radagast here, or at least his appearance seeming to be without meaning, is an obvious symbolic gesture by Jackson, who accords the proper praise to the activist generation. It doesn't mean Radagast is useless. It only means that he appears to be during this phase. Hopefully, he will get his chance in the end.

This entire film is a "set up", but doesn't live on its own. It really needs more. I think "trilogies" are a bit dishonest. It's trying to make us buy 3 books instead of one, to further one's own sales, but it is common in the modern world.

I watched this in 3D, and was happy that Jackson didn't abuse the 3D the way a horror movie geek would. He uses it for a purpose, not just to play games with people. I'm happy about that. It's effective this way, and artistic.

I disagree with the use of a film to simply set up the next film, but it is entertaining, and does give us the characters we realize will make war inevitable. The elf king and river town king are both greedy and selfish on a believable scale. Of the two, the elf king appears the worse of the two, and the one you could never deal with. We see this with the way he honors (or dishonors) a promise to a prisoner.

Obviously, since the film is a "set up" film, it really shouldn't be as lengthy as it is. However, Jackson isn't making this for us today. He's making this for "prosperity", to be appreciated 50 years from now, 300 years from now.

title: Technicks, cuts and not following story line draws down rating
review: I went to this movie and spent A LOT of money for the privilege of watch 3d of a story I have loved for over 40 years. Granted it is a tough area in the story plot line, but the lack of time continuity, which lends realism and anticipation to events, likely ended up on the floor to make way for some of the more "amazing" techniques and special effects. Essentially I feel the only 3d I truly saw that stood out was bumble bees and butterflies. Hardly worth the entrance fees. Seeing this in 2 d would have been just as good. As for the techniques, I don't play video games for a reason. I don't like the "graphics" and the glaring points I saw this, made the filming even less real. Also the conversation and acting was stilted and disjointed in many scenes. This is a joiner movie for the first Hobbit and continuing into Hobbit 3 and then to Lord of the Rings Trilogy. Better to put into the movie what the actors are thinking or how it is affecting the plot rather than long looks where the person watching has to guess what is going on, opposed to one who has read the book and may know what is going on.
